newsitem.title: CHINA: China says MFN foes interfere in internal affairs.
newsitem.headline: China says MFN foes interfere in internal affairs.

text.p: China said on Thursday that some U.S. opponents of its Most Favoured Nation status were trying to politicise the trade issue and use it to interfere in Beijing's internal affairs.

"There are some people in the U.S. who attempt to politicise the MFN issue and use it as a means to interfere in China's internal affairs and pressure China," the Foreign Ministry said in a statement.
"We strongly oppose such a practice which is unwise and will not succeed," the ministry said.
The ministry was replying to a question of its view of statements by U.S. House of Representatives Democratic leader Richard Gephardt urging Congress to revoke China's trading privileges.
U.S. President Clinton announced on May 19 that he would renew MFN for China this year, and opponents were expected to mount the fiercest congressional fight over the issue in years.
Loss of MFN status, which gives preferential treatment to U.S. imports from China, would affect billions of dollars worth of Beijing's trade with the United States.
